elements.name: survey_preamble_header_and_text
elements.html:
Welcome to the End-of-School-Year Survey

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool to remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about our curriculum and your teaching experience.

This survey asks questions about your experience using Code.org in your classroom during this school year. 

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share de-identified, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your de-identified responses will be used by Code.org, our Regional Partners, and our facilitators for program improvement.

At the end, you will be offered a $10 Amazon gift card for your time (supplies limited to first 1000 respondents).

This survey should take less than 10 minutes to complete.  Your complete honesty and candor are appreciated.

elements.name: section1_teaching_context
elements.html:
Teaching Context

This survey is about teaching with Code.org materials and resources during the 2023-24 school year.

The purpose of this survey is to understand better who our teachers are, their motivation to use the Code.org curriculum and tools, as well as some questions about professional development preferences.

Let's get started!

elements.title: Which best describes you?

elements.title: What other role best describes you?

elements.title: At what grade levels did you teach this year?

elements.description: (If so, please select all that apply)

elements.name: section_pd_experience
elements.html: Computer Science Professional Learning Experience

elements.name: pd_experience
elements.title: Have you participated in a professional learning program for teaching Computer Science?

choices.text: Yes, in one or more of Code.org's facilitator-led professional learning programs
Yes, in a facilitator-led professional learning program led by an organization different from Code.org
Yes, in one or more of Code.org's online, self-paced professional learning modules.
Yes, in one or more online, self-paced professional learning content offered by an organization different from Code.org
No, I have not participated in a professional learning program for teaching computer science

elements.name: section_teaching_cdo
elements.html: Your Experience Teaching with Code.org

elements.name: cdo_goal
elements.title: What is your main goal for using Code.org in your classroom?

choices.text: Teaching a full computer science course using Code.org's curriculum and activities (e.g. CS Fundamentals / CS Discoveries / CS Principles / Computer Science A)
Teaching some specific Code.org units or lessons that align with my curriculum
Exposing students to some computer science concepts through some Code.org content and activities
Providing educational activities to my students to do on their own

elements.name: cdo_goal_other_comment
elements.title: Please share what is your main goal for using Code.org in your classroom?

elements.name: use_other_cs_providers
elements.title: Do you use other education providers to teach computer science?

choices.text: Yes, most of the time I use another provider and complement instruction with Code.org content
Yes, I use content from both Code.org and other providers somewhat evenly
Yes, most of the time I use Code.org content and sometimes complement with content from other providers

elements.name: other_cs_providers_select
elements.title: Which other education providers do you use to teach computer science?

elements.name: other_cs_providers_other_comment
elements.title: What other Computer Science education providers do you use to teach?

elements.name: role_as_teacher_using_cdo
elements.title: When your students are using Code.org, what is usually your role in the classroom?

choices.text: I actively teach the entire lesson
I introduce the lesson, then students go at their pace and I am a resource for them
Students engage with Code.org while I work with small groups of students on core subjects, grade, or do other classroom admin work
Students engage with Code.org as a choice during their free work time

elements.name: assigned_or_chose_to_teach
elements.title: Which of the following most closely applies to you about teaching computer science this school year?

choices.text: I was assigned to teach the course
I chose to teach the course
I don't teach a computer science course, I integrate some Code.org activities in my curriculum

elements.name: cs_content_amount
elements.title: How do you feel about the amount of computer science content you are currently teaching?

choices.text: I would like to teach more content than I currently do (e.g. additional units, additional courses)
I am teaching as much as I want to teach and my students need
I  would like to teach less content than I currently do (e.g. less units, fewer or shorter courses)

elements.name: cs_time_per_week
elements.title: On average, how many HOURS PER WEEK does a typical section of your computer science class meet?

choices.text: More than half an hour and up to one hour
More than one and up to two hours
More than two and up to three hours
More than three and up to four hours
More than four and up to five hours

I won't be teaching any longer

choices.text: I am moving to a new school and don't know the schedule yet
I don't know the schedule yet
I don't know yet what my plans are for next school year

elements.name: cs_plans_next_sy_reasons_not_sure_other_comment
elements.title: Please describe the main reason why you don't know if you will teach computer science next school year.

elements.title: Are you planning to use Code.org in your classroom next school year?

elements.name: cdo_plans_next_sy_reasons_no
elements.title: Please select the reason(s) why you don't plan to use Code.org next school year

choices.text: I have developed my own computer science materials
I no longer need to teach computer science concepts
Another computer science provider works better for my classroom

Code.org's teaching tools did not meet my needs (e.g. progress tracking, feedback, grading, etc.)

elements.name: section2_using_cdo_header
elements.html: Using Code.org in Your Classroom

elements.name: section2_using_cdo_description
elements.html: The questions in this section aim to understand your teaching experience with Code.org during the 2023-24 school year.

elements.name: teach_cs_cdo_easy
elements.title: How easy is it to teach computer science using code.org?

elements.name: cdo_effective

elements.name: teaching_resources_space
teaching_resources_matrix
elements.title: How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about Code.org's teaching resources (lesson plans and slides)?

rows.text: I used the lesson plans every time I taught a Code.org lesson
I found it easy to teach a lesson following the lesson plans that are part of Code.org's curriculum
When I use Code.org's lesson plans, teaching new content is easier than when I don't
I used the lesson slides every time I taught a Code.org lesson

elements.name: cdo_features_space
cdo_features_intro
elements.html: In the following two questions please select the top two reasons why you opt for Code.org when choosing a computer science curriculum and tool.

elements.name: features_main_choice
elements.title: What is the most important reason why you opt for Code.org?

choices.text: Code.org's curriculum affords a high-quality learning experience for my students
I have access to teacher forums when I need to troubleshoot
If I report a problem, I receive a timely response
If I submit a question or support request, I receive a timely response
It is constantly updated with new features and content
I can use code.org's curriculum resources (lesson plans, slides, examples, guides and forums) to prepare my lessons
My students have used it before so they are already familiar with it
It is recognized by other organizations as high quality (e.g. Common Sense Media, CSTA, etc.)

elements.name: features_second_choice
elements.title: What is the second most important reason why you opt for Code.org?

choices.text: Code.org's curriculum affords a high-quality learning experience for my students
I have access to teacher forums when I need to troubleshoot
If I report a problem, I receive a timely response
If I submit a question or support request, I receive a timely response
It is constantly updated with new features and content
I can use code.org's curriculum resources (lesson plans, slides, examples, guides and forums) to prepare my lessons
My students have used it before so they are already familiar with it
It is recognized by other organizations as high quality (e.g. Common Sense Media, CSTA, etc.)

elements.name: section3_new_content_cdo_header
elements.html: Expanding Code.org Curriculum

elements.name: section3_new_content_cdo_description
elements.html: At Code.org we are exploring different ways to expand our curriculum to better meet your interests and needs. Your answers to the following questions will inform what new content to design for you and your students.

elements.name: more_content_additional
elements.title: What additional computer science content would you want to teach?

choices.text: Computer science integrated into other subjects

elements.name: 6_12_standalone_units_likelihood
elements.title: If Code.org were to offer new units, 2-8 weeks in length, on specific topics such as data science or AI, designed for students in grades 6-12, how likely would you be to teach them?

elements.name: 6_12_standalone_units_reasons
elements.title: Please share some reasons why you wouldn't be likely to teach short units for students in grades 6-12, on specific topics such as data science or AI.

choices.text: Content overlaps with what I already teach
I don't have time to teach more than I already do
I need more preparation and deeper subject knowledge
Scheduling constraints: adding new content to students' schedules is challenging
There isn't enough support/interest by administrators

elements.name: 6_12_standalone_units_reasons_other_comment
elements.title: Please share what are some other reasons why you are not likely to teach short units on specific topics such as data science or AI.

elements.name: 9_12_cs_foundations_likelihood
elements.title: If Code.org were to offer a semester-long, introductory course about foundations of computer science, for students in grades 9-12, how likely would you be to teach it?  This course would be aligned to State and CSTA standards and would not be an AP course.

elements.name: 9_12_cs_foundations_reasons
elements.title: Please share some reasons why you are not likely to teach an introductory course about foundations of computer science, for students in grades 9-12.

choices.text: I already teach a course like this
I would rather teach an AP course
I don't have time to teach more than I already do
I need more preparation and deeper subject knowledge
Scheduling constraints: adding new content to students' schedules is challenging
There isn't enough support/interest by administrators

elements.name: 9_12_cs_foundations_reasons_other_comment
elements.title: Please share what are some other reasons why you are not likely to teach an introductory course about foundations of computer science.

elements.name: k_5_standalone_units_likelihood
elements.title: If Code.org were to offer short modules, a week or less in length, on focused topics such as game development or AI, designed for students in elementary school (K-5), how likely would you be to teach them?

elements.name: k_5_cross_curricular_content
elements.title: Would you (or your colleagues) be interested in teaching short units (three to five lessons long) that incorporate computer science concepts while teaching core subject standards of the following areas?
elements.description: (Please select all that you (or your colleagues) would be likely to teach)

elements.name: k_5_cross_curricular_content_other_comment
elements.title: What other subjects would you like to see integrated into our computer science curriculum?

elements.name: customized_teaching_space
customized_teaching_matrix
elements.title: How interested would you be in using the following features to customize the Code.org content you teach?

rows.text: Grouping existing lessons to create your own curriculum
Creating your own assessments to assign to students
Creating your own puzzles and activities to assign to students

elements.name: customized_teaching_other
elements.title: If there are any other ways in which you would want to customize the Code.org content you teach, please describe them.

elements.name: section5_teaching_ai_header
elements.html: Teaching Artificial Intelligence and Computer Science

elements.name: section5_teaching_ai_description
elements.html: The following are questions about your experience and interests in teaching Artificial Intelligence (AI). Your responses will provide insight as we develop curriculum for this content.

elements.name: ai_familiarity
elements.title: How familiar are you with AI concepts and content?

elements.name: ai_teaching_experience
elements.title: Have you taught AI content in a K-12 classroom?

choices.text: Yes, using mostly content from another provider
Yes, using mostly content I developed myself

elements.name: ai_teaching_interest
elements.title: Are you interested in more AI content for your classroom?

choices.text: Maybe, I am not very familiar with the existing content

elements.name: ai_teaching_topics
elements.title: What AI topics are you most interested in having more content on?

choices.text: An overview of AI: what it is, how it works, main topics and uses
AI-generated text and images (e.g. ChatGPT, DALL-E)
AI in other subjects (e.g. ELA, history)
How AI is affecting jobs, industries and society
Computer sensing (e.g. sound and vision sensing)

elements.name: ai_teaching_barriers
elements.title: Which of the following do you see as barriers to implementing new AI curriculum at your school?

choices.text: I would like to understand AI better before introducing it to my students
I don't have time to teach more than I already do
I don't have support from my school's administration
I don't have support from other teachers
I need training on how to teach AI
I'm nervous about introducing AI to my students
My school restricts access to AI tools

elements.name: ai_teaching_barriers_other_comment
elements.title: What other barriers do you think could prevent you from implementing new AI curriculum at your school?

elements.name: ai_teaching_comments
elements.title: Is there anything you would like us to know as we think about future AI content development?

elements.name: teaching_background_header
elements.html:
Your Background

Lastly, we'd like to know a little bit about you and your background.

elements.title: What is your gender identity?

choices.text: Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander

elements.title: Is there anything else you’d like to tell us about your experience teaching with Code.org?

elements.html: Thanks from Code.org for your time, commitment and passion for teaching.

elements.name: gift_card_conf_header
elements.html:
Amazon Gift Card Confirmation

Please accept a small token of appreciation in the form of an Amazon gift card, while supplies last.*

*First 1000 respondents will receive gift card. Please allow 1-2 weeks to receive the code.

elements.name: permission
elements.title: I give Code.org permission to quote my written feedback from today for use on social media, promotional materials, and other communications.

Yes, I give permission to quote me, but I want to be anonymous.
No, I do not give permission to quote me.
